comments.author: komisariatku
comments.body: Sounds like you need a longer prologue so I know what your question means.As little as I know, the idea of ​​political economy is an idea about political and economic power in a community/country. Early figures of political economy ideas appeared in the 17th century. This idea was born from the philosopher and economist Adam Smith. During its journey, in the 20th century, political economy split into two main camps, namely the left-wing movement pioneered by Karl Marx with the ideology of Marxism and the right-wing movement with liberal and conservative ideologies.To be able to carry out political economy, there are several foundations that need attention1# Political power2# Economic system3# Public policy4# Market5# Etc (I forget)  I think this discussion is too theoretical and I've forgotten a lot of theory. Maybe that's what I can answer and what little I still remember in my head

comments.author: serjent05
comments.body: From looking at the meaning of political economy, I find that it is the study of the relationship between the government and its national public when public policy is enacted[1]So I think this is more on laying rules and policies of the government regarding the nation's economic activity.  From the given article it is stated that:QuoteThe field of political economy involves the study of how economic theories such as capitalism or communism play out in the real world.As political parties come to and leave power, economic policy often changes due to the ideology and goals of the party in power.Those who study political economy seek to understand how history, culture, and customs impact an economic system, and vice versa.Global political economy studies how political forces shape global economic interactionsThe rise of globalism and global trade means that the political economy of one country can impact both the economy and the politics of others.I believe this topic is too broad and too deep but of course, it is very interesting to see how this discussion progress.[1] https://www.investopedia.com/terms/p/political-economy.asp

comments.author: SmartGold01
comments.body: Actually is been awhile I draw out time to study about this but was little out of point so I just quickly sneak into google to get some smooth view of what it's; Political economy is a branch of political science and economics studying economic systems (e.g. markets and national economies) and their governance by political systems (e.g. law, institutions, and government). Widely studied phenomena within the discipline are systems such as labour markets and financial markets, as well as phenomena such as growth, distribution, inequality, and trade, and how these are shaped by institutions, laws, and government policy. Originating in the 16th century, it is the precursor to the modern discipline of economics. Political economy in its modern form is considered an interdisciplinary field, drawing on theory from both political science and modern economics. From wikipedia

comments.author: Gozie51
comments.body: You could have asked a question to reflect your topic which is a sensitive one and very good also. Listening those items like you did would have given responses that will make your thread very much intellectual one. Not withstanding the lacuna of merging your thoughts together, Political economy is not discussed differently from politics as it affects the economy. That said, we have to look at politics which is basically the alliances formed to get government policies formed, execution or order of priority, likewise the economic policies. So it is basically the policies of economy in order of priority, which policies interacts to influence which policies. Politics is about lobbying also, compromise, alignments and priority. How politics affects or influence government policies is of top consideration in policy formation.
